awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Closed-loop Optimization and Control of Physical Networks Subject to Dynamic Costs, Constraints, and Disturbances
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance a fundamentally new control framework, utilizing streams of heterogeneous data to optimize the behavior of complex and dynamic networked systems with pervasive sensing and computing capabilities, operating in uncertain and changing environments. Existing workhorse control and optimization methodologies assume a large separation of time scales, sufficient to justify complete decoupling of the optimization and control tasks. However, this assumption is increasingly invalid for modern critical infrastructure and social platforms. This project represents a new approach for optimal and reliable decision-making on time scales comparable to the dynamics of the underlying physical and logistic systems, by using new mathematical principles of analysis and synthesis to control the collective behavior of agents and the underlying physical dynamics. The key concept is to continuously drive the dynamical system towards solution trajectories of optimization problems that have costs, constraints, and inputs which change over time. In the context of future transportation networks, the approach is well-aligned with the objective of moving people and cargo efficiently and sustainably, and with the integration of connected and autonomous vehicles. Similar application opportunities occur in areas such as energy, robotics, and autonomous systems, with the common feature of interconnected cooperative and non-cooperative agents interacting via multiple heterogeneous physical and virtual networks. The project will also impact undergraduate and graduate engineering students, and K-12 students through a comprehensive outreach and educational plan that includes STEM camps, engaging activities to promote the recruitment of female students and students from under-served communities and minority schools into the STEM pipeline, and curriculum enhancement initiatives.

Traditional decision-making architectures in networked systems and critical infrastructures are grounded on explicit spatio-temporal boundaries between model-based network-level optimization (producing setpoints in a feed-forward fashion) and local closed-loop control (regulating the dynamical system to the setpoints while rejecting disturbances). The modus operandi of these traditional architectures has worked well in settings where the underlying dynamics of the physical systems are slower than the solution time required by network-level optimization tasks, network models and data structures are available, and problem inputs can be pervasively collected in a timely and reliable manner. Such assumptions, however, are becoming increasingly inadequate in dynamic settings where batch approaches fail to solve the underlying optimization problems on a time scale that matches the dynamics of the networked physical systems, physical models (embedded into the optimization task) are difficult to estimate accurately, and (unknown) disturbances evolve rapidly and unpredictably. This project will generate new mathematical principles for the synthesis and analysis of online data-based algorithms that drive the collective behavior of agents and physical dynamics to desired operational points. In particular, the desired equilibrium points coincide with solution trajectories of time-varying optimization problems formalizing performance metrics and operational constraints associated with the dynamical system. The interconnected-system framework under study compresses the time scales between control and optimization tasks to continuously drive the dynamic behavior of physical systems to network-optimal and stable points. The research seeks to expand the class of problems to which this project vision can be applied, develop predictive controllers with information streams, and synthesize novel distributed algorithmic solutions for interconnected systems.  The technical approach focuses on networked transportation systems as the arena to materialize the theoretical and algorithmic advances and provide innovative control and optimization strategies. Beyond transportation, benefits are expected to propagate in the broader optimization and control communities, with applications in multiple domains including control of epidemics, robotic networks, social networks, and energy infrastructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Constrained optimization problems arise in a myriad applications, often interconnected with dynamical physical processes or "plants". Examples include power systems (e.g., providing optimal setpoints for a distribution grid), transportation networks (e.g., managing in and outflows of a regional network), robotics (e.g., determining optimal control commands within hardware limitations), and learning (e.g., providing exploratory actions that are safe in an unknown environment). In such scenarios, the optimization problem encodes desirable performance objectives and constraints (possibly dynamic and time-varying) of the plant at equilibrium. Online feedback optimization seeks to design feedback laws that steer the inputs and outputs of the plant towards the solution trajectory of the time-varying optimization problem.  The main outcome of the project has been the design and analysis of new algorithms and tools for the optimization and control of network systems operating in dynamic and stochastic environments.

On the intellectual merit side, the project has significantly advanced the state of the art on the design of feedback controllers along three main lines, making special emphasis on the precise characterization of performance and the effect of noise and uncertainty on the system behavior: (i) going beyond focus on static or unconstrained time-varying problems to expand the domain of applicability of online optimization controllers to dynamic scenarios; (ii) using experimental data to bypass the need for explicit model representations of the dynamical system for the synthesis of controllers for unknown stochastic linear dynamical systems, unknown switched linear systems, swing dynamics from power systems, and point-to-point reconfiguration of unknown bilinear control systems; (iii) interconnecting the plant dynamics with dynamical systems that solve constrained nonlinear optimization problems while making the feasible set forward invariant and asymptotically stable.  Bypassing the need for modeling in our approach comes with important advantages: computational savings by avoiding system identification, circumventing uncertainty propagation and its conservative impact on model accuracy, and less data required for control synthesis than for full identification of the dynamics. The invariance of the feasible set makes the proposed algorithms particularly suitable when the constraints on the optimization problem encode the safe operation of physical plants.  In such cases, it is desirable that the algorithm is anytime, meaning that it is guaranteed to return a feasible point even when terminated before it has converged to a solution. The anytime property ensures that the specifications conveyed to the plant remain feasible at all times.

On the broader impacts side, our research effort has advanced our ability to learn optimized controls for complex dynamical systems. The technical findings provide a fundamentally new principle for the design of feedback controllers for dynamical systems operating in dynamic environments. The formulation of time-varying optimization problems associated with dynamical systems is unique to this project: the methodologies to synthesize and analyze the interconnection between the proposed feedback controllers and the dynamical system provides contributions to the broader control community. Our work on anytime optimization for constrained optimization problems has resulted in a suite of versatile, provably correct algorithms that are able to guarantee the safe operation of physical infrastructure in multiple domains.  The project has implemented the results on realistic scenarios from power networks (distributed power injections, optimal frequency control, transient safety), transportation systems (ramp metering, traffic light, traffic flow, and mobility-on-demand control), and robotics (ground differential-drive robots).  In our tests, the flexibility and generality of the concept behind our approach to the synthesis of optimization-based controllers has enabled us to outperform well-established control methods in the transportation literature.  The project also positively impacts the design of real-time optimization and control methods for settings where the operation of the transportation and power infrastructures are interconnected, requiring joint optimization.  As the results and ideas developed under this project become known to a larger audience, we believe they will have a positive impact on the design of real-time optimization and control methods for interconnected settings where one seeks to optimally regulate physical infrastructures.  The research has made an impact in the training of a new generation of scientists and engineers at UC San Diego, from incoming undergraduate students all the way to the postdoctoral scholar level, who have developed the skills necessary to deal with the type of multi­faceted systems and applications considered in the project.  Specific outcomes include mentoring and supervision of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students, lab tours and outreach activities to incoming freshman, transfer, high school, and middle school students to provide motivation to engage in STEM disciplines.  The results have been disseminated through conference and journal publications, online availability of preprints and publications, invited research talks delivered at top institutions, invited plenary talks at conferences and other professional research meetings, various roles in workshop and conference organization, instruction at summer schools, and organization of special issues in archival publications.
